data.title: Conflict: a Distributed Condition: Contemporary War Ecologies
data.desc:
Conflict is not an exception or an isolated event — it is a constant condition running through society. It is not limited to war or explicit clashes: it emerges within collective life as friction, as a continuous confrontation between competing needs, systems, and visions.
It is not a punctual episode but a latent and distributed condition. It takes on asymmetric, often invisible forms, embedded in cultural practices, social relations, and infrastructures. Its logic is not confined to violence: it also structures coexistence, shaping who holds privilege and who is pushed to the margins.
Exploring distributed conflicts means reading the present as a field where techniques of offense multiply and blur into the infrastructures society depends on. The goal is to generate critical devices, scenarios, and questions that probe the ambiguous nature of conflict as a diffuse condition in a post-territorial age.

data.title: Definition of Conflict
data.desc:
Positive: costitutive condition of living together. It's the result of the human plurality. It could be positive confront, structural antagonism that moves history. 

Negative: conflict as a consequence of power-resistance dynamics, and as the base of institutions.
links: Jean-Luc Nancy, Hanna Arendt, Marx, Nietzche, Foucault

data.title: Definition of Infrastructure
data.desc: Complementary works necessary for the performance of an activity (roads, railways, aqueducts, telecommunication networks, digital). They are the foundation of the main structure, necessary for the economic and social development of a country.

data.title: Physical Infrastructures
data.desc: Material and tangible components necessary for the functioning of society and the economy, including transportation systems (roads, railways, ports), essential services (energy, water, telecommunications), buildings, and, in the IT sector, data centers, servers, and networking equipment.

data.title: Technological and Digital Infrastructures
data.desc: The set of hardware, software, networks, and data centers that enable the management of digital data and resources, supporting the daily activities and growth strategies of organizations and society. Key elements include data centers, storage systems, networking equipment (routers and switches), cloud platforms, and data processing systems, making connectivity, security, and efficiency of digital processes possible.

data.title: Social Infrastructures
data.desc: The set of assets functional to meeting essential collective needs, particularly in the areas of education, healthcare, and housing.

data.title: Law & Order and Institutional Infrastructures
data.desc: Law & Order infrastructure refers to the systems, institutions, and resources that uphold public safety, enforce laws, and guarantee justice. It includes courts, police, prisons, and regulatory bodies, ensuring stability and protection of rights.

data.title: Economical and financial Infrastructures
data.desc: Economic and financial infrastructure refers to the set of institutions, markets, and systems that enable the functioning of the economy. It includes banks, stock exchanges, payment systems, insurance, and credit networks. These ensure the circulation of money, investment management, and the stability of transactions. Their efficiency is crucial for a country’s development and growth.

data.title: Cultural Infrastructures
data.desc: The set of material and immaterial elements (structures, spaces, technologies, communities, traditions, collections) that make up a territory’s cultural heritage and facilitate its enjoyment, development, and preservation, while promoting creativity and local identity.

data.title: Infrastructural conflict
data.desc: situation of contrast, opposition, and tension, that regards the project, localisation, realisation, management, resignation of an infrastructure (physical or immaterial).

data.title: First topics brainstorm
data.desc:
- Security cameras, big brother, conflict in surveillance
- Construction of Infrastructures that then self-damage
- Transport Infrastructures designed for AI, instead of humans 
- Bureaucracy (as an infrastructure itself) blocking infrastructures 
- Military mobility in Europe: infrastructures + customs/technical limits
- Infrastructure as a network 
- Cyber warfare
- Corruption
- Infrastructure crises caused by war
- ‘Evolutionary’ differences of infrastructures in different places
- Infrastructures that arise because of conflict 
- Walls as infrastructure creating separation
- Playful/Ludic infrastructure
- Pop-up walls (temporary or movable barriers)
- Gentrification
- Satellites and the space race 
- Energy

data.title: Biopower
data.desc: Whereas power was once exercised explicitly and performatively (public executions and torture) and manifested in decisions of life or death, today power is directed toward life itself, specifically its control. Infrastructure plays a fundamental role in this.

data.title: Urbicide
data.desc: "Urbicide” is the deliberate destruction of a city or urban environment, targeting its infrastructure, buildings, and social fabric, often to erase its cultural identity or to weaken the community living there.

data.title: War Necropolitics
data.desc: The infrastructure needed to face a war is not accessible to the entire society. It may be necessary to choose who can be saved and who cannot.

data.title: Necropolitics
data.desc: Necropolitics is a concept by the Cameroonian philosopher Achille Mbembe that describes how political power controls people not only through life (biopolitics) but especially through death, determining who lives and who must die.

data.title: The white man's burden
data.desc: A poem by Kipling in which he describes the “duty” of the European man, presenting the construction of infrastructure as a “colonial aid” for “inferior” peoples, which in reality translates into cultural and social domination.

data.title: War targets riorganized for a socio-economical advantage
Energetic Infrastructures
data.desc: Energy infrastructure refers to the systems, facilities, and equipment needed to generate, transmit, store, and distribute energy. These networks keep our homes warm, our factories running, and our cities moving.

data.title: Sattelits
data.desc: Satellites like Starlink play a crucial role in warfare, providing Internet access in areas without terrestrial infrastructure. In Ukraine, they support military communications, drone control, and real-time data transmission. They enable operational coordination even in active conflict zones, becoming essential on the battlefield. However, they raise geopolitical and security concerns related to the use of private technology in wars.

data.title: Transportation
data.desc: Transportation infrastructure is the physical network that enables the movement of people and goods, including roads, railways, airports, and canals. It is crucial for economic growth, trade, and social well-being, requiring significant investment and planning to ensure safe, efficient, and sustainable systems.

data.title: In Italy
data.desc: Italy has a well-developed transportation infrastructure with extensive networks of highways and railways, including an operational high-speed rail system that ranks among the longest in the world. The country plays a strategic role in the TEN-T Core Network for the EU market, hosting several European Corridors that connect key industrial clusters, ports, and airports.

data.title: Integration of travel in more facets of life
Environmental sustainability vs developement
data.desc: A socio-political and ecological conflict arises when an infrastructure generates severe environmental impacts or redistributes resources in ways that harm ecosystems and livelihoods, while being presented as a driver of development. The conflict stems from the unequal distribution of costs and benefits and from inadequate decision-making processes and remedies.

data.title: Humanitary/Sanitary help vs war target
data.desc: Hospitals, clinics, ambulances, aid distribution centers, and civilian shelters are attacked or threatened during armed conflicts, despite being designed to protect and save lives.

data.title: Instruction palce vs distruction place
data.desc: Between 2022 and 2023, there were approximately 6,000 attacks on schools and universities worldwide, affecting over 10,000 students and teachers, mainly in Palestine, Ukraine, and the DRC. The attacks, including bombings, arson, and military use of schools, caused prolonged closures, loss of months of education, and severe psychological effects. HRW urges states to adopt the Safe Schools Declaration to protect education during conflicts.

data.title: Turism vs Welfare
data.desc: The way the new forms of overtourism are undermining the welfare of local populations

data.title: La città del sole
data.desc: “La città del Sole” (1602) by Tommaso Campanella is a utopian dialogue that describes an ideal society organized in concentric circles, governed by a priest-philosopher called Sun and his magistrates. In it, there is no private property; everything is shared, even families and children. Education is collective and based on symbols and knowledge painted on the city’s walls. It is a model of harmony between religion, science, and politics, set against the injustices of its time.

data.title: Neuroarchitecture
data.desc: Neuroarchitecture is an interdisciplinary field that combines architecture, neuroscience, psychology, and ergonomics to study how built environments influence the brain, emotions, and human behavior.

data.title: Foreigners everywhere: Biennale
data.desc: Foreigners Everywhere, curated by Brazilian Adriano Pedrosa, was the main art exhibition of the 60th Venice Biennale, which took place from April 20–November 24, 2024. Pedrosa's stated intention for the exhibit was to investigate the idea of living on the margins, whether as an outsider, a new arrival, or an Indigenous person.

data.title: Touristification
data.desc: Touristification is the process by which a city or area becomes dominated by tourism. It often transforms local spaces, services, and culture to cater to visitors. This can lead to economic benefits but also social tensions, displacement, and loss of local identity.

data.title: Luxury tourism
data.desc: Luxury tourism (luxury travel) is a segment of the tourism industry dedicated to travelers seeking unique, personalized, and top-level experiences, prioritizing quality, exclusivity, comfort, privacy, and personal fulfillment.

data.title: Extreme turism
data.desc: Forms of tourism practiced in remote, dangerous contexts beyond the jurisdiction of States, such as the deep sea, polar regions, or outer space.

data.title: Overtourism in Venice
data.desc: The entire physical structure of the city, from its foundations to its canals, is unable to withstand the weight of mass tourism, transforming infrastructure from a resource for residents into a source of conflict.

data.title: Jeff Bezos wedding
data.desc: Jeff Bezos’s wedding in Venice drew huge media attention and an exceptional influx of luxury guests. This kind of event amplifies the problems of elite and mass tourism, which already weigh heavily on the city. Residents experienced mobility issues, with difficult travel and restricted access. Venice thus risks becoming a global stage rather than a livable city for its inhabitants.

data.title: Spacial torusim
data.desc: Blue Origin organizes suborbital tourist flights lasting about 11 minutes, reaching altitudes over 100 km. Passengers experience a few minutes of weightlessness while observing the Earth’s curvature through large panoramic windows. The capsule then returns to Earth with a controlled parachute landing. These missions represent an exclusive form of space tourism, reserved for a select few participants.

data.title: Submarine tourism
data.desc: OceanGate organizes private submarine expeditions to the Titanic wreck, offering participants an exclusive experience aboard the Titan submersible. These missions, lasting about 10 days, cost $250,000 per person, excluding travel expenses to the departure point in Newfoundland, Canada. The business model involved passengers, called “citizen scientists,” participating in scientific research missions, but the company faced criticism over safety and operational transparency. After the fatal Titan incident in June 2023, OceanGate suspended all operations and ceased activities.

data.title: Everest Mount
data.desc: In recent years, extreme tourism on Mount Everest has surged, with thousands of climbers visiting each season. This has caused severe overcrowding, long queues to reach the summit, and increased safety risks. The Nepalese government has responded by raising permit fees and limiting the number of climbers to manage environmental and logistical impacts.

data.title: Politics of infrastructure
data.desc: Social, cultural, and political conflict can arise as early as the planning phase of an infrastructure project. Economic interests, community rights, and cultural heritage may come into conflict. The lack of dialogue fuels protests and delays, while construction often disregards human rights and local cultures.

data.title: Messina Strait Bridge
data.desc: Location: Strait of Messina (Sicily–Calabria, Italy). The project involves national governments, local administrations, construction consortia, environmental groups, and citizens, with disputes over real costs, seismic risks, and potential mafia influence. It has been repeatedly launched, suspended, and restarted. The debate remains constant, balancing promises of development against environmental, technical, and economic concerns.

data.title: No Tav
data.desc: The No TAV movement emerged in Val di Susa against the construction of the Turin–Lyon high-speed rail line. It brings together residents, activists, and social groups denouncing environmental, economic, and social impacts. Conflict with the government and law enforcement has led to protests, clashes, and legal proceedings. It has become a national symbol of resistance against top-down large-scale projects.

data.title: ZAD of Notre Dame des Landes
data.desc: In Notre-Dame-des-Landes, near Nantes, France, local farmers, ZAD ecological activists, the government, and the airport industry clashed over a new airport. Legal questions about occupations versus the right to protest fueled tensions. After decades of mobilization and resistance, strong opposition led to the airport’s cancellation in 2018. The case stands as a notable victory for social movements.
